Just before hitting the sea the stone has speed \(v\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 750, 470]]<|/det|> What is the average force of air resistance acting on the stone during its fall? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 482, 133, 501]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 482, 180, 501]]<|/det|> $mg$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 477, 311, 501]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 472, 428, 507]]<|/det|> \[\frac{m(\nu^2 - 2gh)}{h} \qquad \text{C} \quad m\left(g - \frac{\nu^2}{2h}\right) \qquad \text{D} \quad m\left(gh - \frac{\nu^2}{2}\right)\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 542, 106, 560]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 541, 920, 574]]<|/det|> A railway engine accelerates a train of total mass 1200 tonnes (1 tonne = \(1000\mathrm{kg}\)) from rest to a speed of \(75\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 693, 604]]<|/det|> How much useful work must be done on the train to reach this speed? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 615, 133, 633]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 615, 744, 633]]<|/det|> \(3.4 \times 10^{6} \text{J}\) \(6.8 \times 10^{6} \text{J}\) \(3.4 \times 10^{9} \text{J}\) \(6.8 \times 10^{9} \text{J}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 759, 91]]<|/det|>
What is a correct derivation of the equation relating power, force and velocity?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 109, 134, 128]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 103, 653, 139]]<|/det|>
power = \(\frac{\text{work done}}{\text{time taken}}\) and work done = force \(\times\) displacement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 428, 175]]<|/det|>
so power = \(\frac{\text{force} \times \text{displacement}}{\text{time taken}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 180, 376, 201]]<|/det|>
so power = force \(\times\) velocity

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 216, 133, 235]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 211, 611, 247]]<|/det|>
power = \(\frac{\text{work done}}{\text{time taken}}\) and work done = force \(\times\) distance

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 250, 384, 281]]<|/det|>
so power = \(\frac{\text{force} \times \text{distance}}{\text{time taken}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 287, 376, 308]]<|/det|>
so power = force \(\times\) velocity

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 323, 133, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 317, 599, 352]]<|/det|>
power = \(\frac{\text{work done}}{\text{time taken}}\) and work done = \(\frac{\text{force}}{\text{displacement}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 362, 460, 395]]<|/det|>
so power = \(\frac{\text{force}}{\text{displacement}} \times \text{time taken}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 402, 319, 437]]<|/det|>
so power = \(\frac{\text{force}}{\text{velocity}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 457, 134, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 451, 556, 486]]<|/det|>
power = \(\frac{\text{work done}}{\text{time taken}}\) and work done = \(\frac{\text{force}}{\text{distance}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 494, 438, 526]]<|/det|>
so power = \(\frac{\text{force}}{\text{distance}} \times \text{time taken}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 532, 319, 565]]<|/det|>
so power = \(\frac{\text{force}}{\text{velocity}}\)
